title-group.article-title: The Rotem failure criterion for fibrous laminated composite materials: Three-dimensional loading case

article-meta.aff: Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion – Israel Institute of Technology, Israel

author-notes.corresp: Assa Rotem, Faculty of Mechanical Engineering, Technion – Israel Institute of Technology, Haifa 32000, Israel Email: merar01@technion.ac.il

article-meta.issue-title: Special Issue: Evaluation of Theories for Predicting Failure in Polymer Composite Laminates Under 3-D States of Stress: Part A of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II)

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The present article describes the application of Rotem failure criterion to solve 12 test cases employed in the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II). The criterion distinguishes between fiber failure and matrix failures (transverse-isotropic strength and the square of the deviatory and shear strengths). Effect of hydrostatic pressure is taken into account for the matrix dominated failure. The nonlinear progressive model is used to predict three-dimensional failure envelopes and stress strain curves for all 12 test cases, which involved isotropic, unidirectional lamina and multi-directional laminates loaded both through-thickness and in-plane directions. The calculation technique and the final results are given in the article.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In previous articles,1,2 the original Rotem’s failure criterion for fibrous composite materials was presented for the case of two-dimensional (2D) stress conditions where loading is only in the plane of the laminate. For that case, the stress–strain relations applied to the laminate are much simpler than in the general 3D case.3,4 However, for fibrous composite materials, which are used for manufacturing high efficiency laminates, there are some simplifications over the general 3D case.5

First of all, it is assumed that the laminate is made of many unidirectional laminae, laid up in predetermined directions. A special case would be a single lamina, i.e. a unidirectional laminate. The second assumption is that the fibers are much stiffer and stronger than the matrix material. The third assumption is that the fibers are parallel and distributed evenly within the lamina. For further simplicity, we assume isothermal conditions, which mean that the thermal stresses are absent.

With these assumptions, it can be assumed that there is statistical homogeneity within the lamina and it can be treated as orthotropic material exhibiting a transverse isotropy behavior. Thus, for stiffness purposes, the lamina is considered homogenous, but for strength consideration, there is a huge difference between fibers and matrix. In fact, Rotem’s failure criterion distinguishes between failure of the fibers and failure of the matrix as two separate criteria. While the fiber’s failure criterion is similar to the one in the 2D case, the matrix failure criterion is quite different. The suggested failure criteria that are presented here assume some parameters that are needed for the calculations as they cannot be predicted theoretically (only by experiments).

sec.title: 3D failure criterion for isotropic material
sec.p: The first task in this exercise is to predict the failure envelope of a homogenous material, epoxy resin. The unequal strength in tension and compression eliminates the use of classical theories like distortion strain energy (Von Mises failure criterion6). Another important factor for selecting the proper failure criterion is that it should hold for hydrostatic stress situations.

The author believes that perfectly homogenous materials do not fail by hydrostatic pressure. This is because the material contracts by the bulk modulus until the distance between the atoms gets too small to allow for any further contraction. However, if the material is not perfectly homogenous the inner structure may collapse. Usually the hydrostatic strength is very high and involves structure change. Since the information about this issue is not known, the hydrostatic compressive strength would be assumed close to infinity. With these assumptions, the failure criterion for the homogenous material is developed. It is further assumed isothermal conditions and thermal stresses are absent.

Let the stress field in the material be denoted by σij. Separation of the stress field into the isotropic stress field and the deviatory stress field is expressed as (1)σij=σoδij+τij Where (2)σo=13∑σkk=σ11+σ22+σ333 and
The isotropic failure criterion (ifc) is postulated for the two stress fields.

For the isotropic stress (4)ifc=σoFto or ifc=σoFcowithifc=1 Where the compressive strength Fco is very high (in absolute values) and the tensile strength Fto express the stress needed to separate between molecules or atoms. It is very difficult to measure these values experimentally and therefore some relations to standard measurements of tensile and compressive strengths must be adopted.7 (see Appendix 2).

The matrix failure criterion (mfc) for the deviatory and shear stress is assumed as a quadratic convex close surface. It has the following form (5)∑ij(τijFsmij)2=mfc=1 Where for i ≠ j Fsmij is the shear strength and for i = j it is the deviatory strength which is evaluated from the uniaxial testing in tension and compression. Since there is a difference between the tensile and the compressive strengths, these strengths depend on the isotropic stress. Using the tensile and compressive strengths, Ft and Fc, the deviatory strength is evaluated. Bearing in mind that it is stronger for higher isotropic stress (in absolute values) and it is linearly dependent on the isotropic stress σo, it is evaluated as follows (Appendix 2) (6)B=323(-Fc-Ft-Fc+Ft) (7)Fsmkk=-Bσo+Ft(23+13B) forτkk
However, it is assumed that the effect of the isotropic compressive stress on the deviatory shearing strength is limited by the lower bound and therefore σo≥2/3 Fc in this expression (Appendix 2).
The values in expression (4) are estimated as Fto = Ft/1.5 for the upper limit and a number outside the scale (Fco ≪ Fc) for the lower limit (Appendix 2).

Using the above expressions and the data for the resin material, the failure envelope for 3D normal loads were calculated. The results are shown in the graph for test case 1, Figure 1. Figure 1.
Failure envelope for resin material MY750 subjected to three normal stresses with σy = σz (test case 1).

sec.title: 3D failure criterion for fibrous composite unidirectional lamina
sec.p: The failure criterion for fibrous composite laminate follows the previous one1,2 with modifications as in the previous chapter. Thermal effects are not considered here. This time it is treated as a 3D case, and it will be modified accordingly. First of all, the basic criterion for the single lamina will be established. Then failure prediction for the multidirectional laminate will be evaluated.

The single lamina may be treated as a continuum5 for the calculation of the stress field. The fibers direction is unique and therefore the lamina is modelled by orthotropic material with transverse isotropy. For the strength predictions, the media is treated as being composed of two parts, fibers and matrix.

For the fibers, they can fail only by longitudinal normal stress, that is, in tension or compression. The fibers strength in tension, Ftf, defines the strength in the axial direction, Ft1, which is evaluated experimentally. However, the strength depends partly on the connection between fibers and matrix8 and hence on the transverse isotropic stress. The fibers compression strength is governed by micro buckling8 and therefore it might increase due to transverse iso-pressure. This phenomenon may only be verified by experiments. Therefore, the compression strength in the fibers direction, Fc1, is also evaluated experimentally (with or without transverse pressure).
Designating the 3D stress field by 6 indices as (8)σi=[σ1σ4σ6σ4σ2σ5σ6σ5σ3] Where indices 1, 2 and 3 for normal stresses and indices 4, 5 and 6 for shear stresses. The fiber direction is 1.
It must be noted that the stress in the fiber direction is split between fiber and matrix, that is (9) σ1=σf1vf+σm1vm Where (10)σf1=σ1EfE1andσm1=σ1EmE1
However, the fiber’s failure criterion is expressed by σ1 with reference to equation (10) for the real stress in the fibers.
Hence the fiber failure criterion (ffc) is given by (11)σ1Ft1=ffc or σ1Fc1=ffc with ffc = 1 at failure

The fiber compressive strength is influenced by the isotropic transverse stress, because it affects the buckling condition of the fibers. The fiber tensile strength is also influenced by the isotropic transverse stress because it affects the bridging mechanism over broken fibers.9 This will be shown later.

For the matrix, there are two criteria, the isotropic transverse stress and the quadratic deviatory and shear stress. The 3D stress field is divided into two parts, longitudinal stresses and transverse stresses.

Noting that the normal stress along the fibers (in the matrix) is defined by equation (10) and the moduli ratio Ef/Em ≫ 1, the stress σm1 is negligible, so that only the fibers control the failure in the 1 direction. Therefore, separating the stress field to longitudinal and transverse gives (12)σi=σlongitudinal+σtransverse or (13)σi=[σ1σ4σ6σ400σ600]+[0000σ2σ50σ5σ3] Using the unabridged marking for the stresses, the transverse stress field is also separated to transversely isotropic stress and transversely deviatory and shear stress, with α and β may have values of 2 and 3. (14)σαβ=σomδαβ+ταβ Where (15)σom=12∑σββ and (16)ταβ=σαβ-σomδαβ
Once the stress fields are defined, the failure criteria may be formulated.

For the fibers failure criterion (equation (11)), the compressive and tensile strengths are modified due to the transversely isotropic stress as (17)Fc1=Fco1(1+K1σomFcom) Ft1=Fto1(1+KoσomFtom) Where Ko and K1 are influence factors. As in the previous case (isotropic) these values must be defined by experimental testing. However, since we do not have this data they are estimated by a reasonable value of 0.5 based on previous experience.10 The strengths Fco1 and Fto1 are the fibers compressive and tensile strengths without transverse pressure. Fcom is the transversely isotropic compressive strength, estimated as the fiber compressive strength (Fco1 = Fcom) and Ftom is the transversely isotropic tensile strength, estimated as (18) Ftom=2*Fty Where Fty is the experimental value of the transverse tensile strength of a single unidirectional lamina, not embedded in a laminate.

Hence, the transversely isotropic failure criterion (tifc) is (19)σomFcom=tifc or σomFtom=tifcwithtifc=ms The deviatory and shear stress failure criterion (dfc) is expressed by (20)∑ij(τijFsij)2=dfcwithdfc=ms2(whileτ11=0)
For single unidirectional lamina ms = 1.

The strength parameters Fsij for i ≠ j, are defined experimentally and modified for transversely isotropic stress, as it influences their values. Accordingly (21)Fs1α=Fs1α(1+K2σomFcα) with K2 estimated by 0.05.

The remaining strength parameters Fsαα are defined by the experimentally measured transverse tensile and compressive strengths. Assuming linear change between these values (absolute), this expression has the form (22)Bα=(-Fcα-Ftα-Fcα+Ftα) and (23)Fsαα=Ftα2(1+Bα)-22Bασom Where α may have the values 2 or 3, and Fs23 is the experimental value for the transverse shear strength.
Using these criteria and the materials data, test cases 2 to 7 were calculated. The results are shown in the appropriate graphs.

sec.title: 3D failure criterion for fibrous composite laminate
sec.p: Failure of the laminate starts with failure of the unidirectional lamina. As was shown above, the lamina may fail either by fibers or by matrix. When the stress in the lamina’s matrix reaches the failure stress, the neighbors laminae which bridges over the initiated crack, resist its starting and propagating. This effect is similar to an increase in the strength parameters tifc and dfc. Moreover, the initiation of one crack does not exclude the lamina from supporting the applied load. Only after accumulation of certain amount of cracks, the lamina becomes ineffective. It was found9 that crack initiation starts at 20% higher stress level. It was also found that many other cracks starts in the lamina with stress increasing up to final failure of the lamina. The stress level to which it may go depend on the angle between the lamina direction (its fibers) and the direction of neighbors laminae. Therefore, for each lamina the initial failure criterion value is ms = 1.2 and the final failure value (24)ml(j)=ms+K3abs(sin(La(j))) Where La(j) is the angle between the laminae and K3 = 0.25 is fitting factor9 defined experimentally.

Cracks accumulation causes the stiffness of the laminate to decrease, because the moduli of the lamina degrade (except the modulus in the fiber direction E1). The degradation process is described by (25)M=M(1-K4log(dfc)) Where M=E2,E3,G12,G13,G23 and ms2 < dfc < ml(j)2

K4 is a factor which bound the degradation to 0.01 M. Moreover, the bridging effect of the laminae causes 20% increase in the axial shear moduli G12 and G13, as they resist the shear strain. Therefore, in the calculation of the stresses, the moduli are multiplied by 1.2. This increase is applicable to all multidirectional laminates used in this exercise. On the other hand, if the lamina fails by fiber fracture or collapse, the failure process is very rapid and practically the lamina becomes inefficient immediately.

Therefore, the laminate failure criterion, consist of the lamina failure criterion for the initiation of the first crack in each lamina, followed by crack accumulation and stiffness degradation until final failure of the lamina. At the same time, fiber failure or transversely isotropic stress failure may cause immediate ineffectiveness of the lamina. Meanwhile or afterwards, other laminae undergo the same process until the laminate can no longer support the applied loads. It has to be remembered that all the strength values are statistically distributed and therefore the predictions are average values.

sec.title: Calculation of the criteria
sec.p:
The basic assumption is that all laminae are perfectly bonded. It means for these cases (no moments are applied) that the strain field in all laminae is the same. The necessary steps for the calculation of the failure criteria are as follows:
Calculation of the compliances, Sij, of a single lamina in its principal coordinate axes, was made using its elastic moduli. For the nonlinear stress–strain curves, see the relevant equations in Appendix 3, a step-wise incremental analysis was adopted.
Rotation of the compliances of each lamina around the Z axis to the X direction by the inclined angle. First transform the compliances to 4 indices notation. Then apply the specific transformation tensor for each lamina (caution: not the plane rotation but the 3D rotation) (26)[S']k=[T]k[S]k
Then back to 2 indices notation of Sij '.
Sum up the compliances on all the laminae thicknesses to get the reciprocal of the laminate's stiffness (3D) (27)Aij -1=∑kSijk 'hkh2
Apply a load step and find the laminate strains (3D) (28)ɛxi=Aij -1Nj
Rotate the laminate strains to each lamina principal direction (29)[ɛ]k=[T]k[ɛx]
Store the result and input it in step (1) to get the strain related moduli. Repeat the calculation loop until the strains difference is negligible.
Reciprocate the lamina compliance matrix to get the moduli matrix (30)Cij=Sij -1
Calculate the stresses in each lamina (31)σi=Cijɛj
Check the failure criteria for each lamina as described above. If none of them was satisfied, increase a load step and return to step (4). When one of the lamina fails, mark it as initial failure for this load. Return to step {1} and use equation (25) to input the degrade moduli. Add a load step and continue the calculation. Final failure of the lamina would be, when the failure criteria are satisfied with values of dfc = ml(j)2, tifc = ml(j) or ffc = 1. Mark the load as final failure of the lamina. Continue to step (4) with increased load.
When all the laminae fail then the laminate fails and this represents a final laminate failure for this specific load combination.
For stress–strain curve the calculations are completed once those above steps have been performed once. For failure envelope, start with another load combination until the whole range is covered.

sec.title: Evaluation of the cases
sec.p:
The present failure criteria were employed to analyze the 12 test cases that were proposed by Kaddour and Hinton,11 as a part of the Second World-Wide Failure Exercise (WWFE-II). Details of the materials, lay-up and loading conditions are described in Kaddour and Hinton.11 These include a pure polymer material, unidirectional laminae and multi-directional laminates. Both glass and carbon unidirectional plies were used. Loadings involve triaxial stresses and combined through-thickness and shear stresses. The results of the calculations are presented in Figures 1 to 12. Figure 2.
Failure envelope for T300/PR319 unidirectional lamina, subjected to three equal normal stresses acting on the principal axes and axial shear stress (test case 2). Failure modes identification: 1 – ffc-c (fibers failure, compression), 2 –ffc-t (fibers failure, tension), 3 – tifc (isotropic stress failure), 4 – dfc (matrix shear failure). Figure 3.
Failure envelope for test case 3, showing the variation of failure shear strain with hydrostatic pressure. Figure 4.
Axial shear stress–strain curve for T300/PR319 unidirectional lamina which subjected to 3D constant compression stresses of −600 MPa (test case 4). Figure 5.
Failure envelope of unidirectional lamina made of E-glass/MY750 epoxy loaded by 3D normal stresses with two of them being equal (test case 5). Failure modes identification: 1 – ffc-c (fibers failure, compression), 2 –ffc-t (fibers failure, tension), 3 – tifc (isotropic stress failure), 4 – dfc (matrix shear failure). Figure 6.
Failure envelope of unidirectional lamina made of S-glass/epoxy, loaded by 3D normal stresses with two of them being equal (test case 6). Failure modes identification: 1 – ffc-c (fibers failure, compression), 2 –ffc-t (fibers failure, tension), 3 – tifc (isotropic stress failure), 4 – dfc (matrix shear failure). Note that the cut-off at σ2 = σ3 = −1150 MPa is due to constant transverse isotropic stress which cause the failure. Figure 7.
Failure envelope of unidirectional lamina made of A-S carbon/epoxy, loaded by 3D normal stresses with two of them being equal (test case 7). Failure modes identification: 1 – ffc-c (fibers failure, compression), 2 –ffc-t (fibers failure, tension), 3 – tifc (isotropic stress failure), 4 – dfc (matrix shear failure). Note that the cut-off at σ2 = σ3 = −1500 MPa is due to constant transverse isotropic stress which cause the failure. Figure 8.
Failure Envelope of [±35]s laminate made of E-glass/MY750 epoxy, loaded by 3-D normal stresses with two of them being equal. Failure modes identification: 1 – ffc-c (fibers failure, compression), 2 –ffc-t (fibers failure, tension), 3 – tifc (isotropic stress failure), 4 – dfc (matrix shear failure). Figure 9.
Stress–strain curves for [±35]s laminate made of E-glass/MY750 epoxy (test case 9). Initially the laminate is loaded by three equal normal compressive stresses of −100 MPa, then the compressive stress in the Y direction is increased until failure while in the other directions it remains −100 MPa. The laminate fails by shear mode. First crack at σy = −244 MPa. Final failure at σy = −263 MPa. Figure 10.
Failure envelope of [0/90/±45]s laminate made of IM7/8551-7 material, subjected to out-of-plane normal and shear loads while σx = σy = 0 (test case 10). The onset of the first crack was in the 90 lamina, except for very low shear where it occurs at the 0 lamina. The calculation shows that the final failure occurs at the −45 lamina. Figure 11.
Failure envelope of [0/90]s laminate made of IM7/8551-7 material, subjected to out-of-plane normal and shear loads while σx = σy = 0 (test case 11). The onset of the first crack was in the 90 lamina, except for very low shear where it occurs at the 0 lamina. The calculation shows that the final failure occurs at the 0 lamina. Figure 12.
Stress–strain curves for [0/90]s laminate made of IM7/8551-7 material, subjected to out-of-plane normal load while σx = σy = 0 (test case 12). Failure mode is Shear in the matrix. The peculiar shape of the curve is due to extension (negative) mode that was imposed on the experiment, reflecting the nonlinearities of shear and extension moduli. The failure initiation was at a level of 396 MPa in either of the laminae. The final failure was at a level of 417 MPa.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The failure theories presented here distinguish between isotropic homogenous materials and anisotropic composite materials. However, some similarity exists. In both cases, the isotropic stress, especially pressure, play an important role in the failure criteria. Unfortunately the provided strength data were based on standard experiments and does not include some parameters that are needed for these criteria. Therefore some parameters were estimated based on previous experience with other composite materials.

The criterion for the isotropic homogenous material is a true 3D criterion where the pressure and shear dominate the failure. Since there is a difference between the strengths in tension and compression, five parameters are needed to evaluate the strength for all possible loadings.

The criterion for composite laminate is the same as for lamina. Since the criterion is based on the stress state in each lamina within the laminate, the calculation is more complex. Because the material (the lamina) is assumed orthotropic with one preferred direction (fiber direction), transverse directions are ‘isotropic’. For 3D loading, nine parameters are needed and four influence factors. These parameters are not necessarily the ones provided to us here. Some manipulations were needed to come to the right ones. The prediction procedure for final failure of standing alone unidirectional lamina and the prediction procedure for initiation of failure for multidirectional laminate are the same (with different moduli). Only after accumulation of cracks the lamina within the laminate fails. Cracks in the laminae degrade the stiffness of each lamina and therefore alters the stress state. Because the matrix dependent moduli are nonlinear and occurrences of cracks causes degradation, calculation of the strain and stress fields are quite complicated. Nevertheless, the calculation program is very robust and in all the tested cases the convergence was excellent. This fact gives hope that this failure criterion may be used to predict strength of laminates subjected to very complicated loadings.
A comparison between the predictions obtained from the present theory and those employed by other participants of the WWFE-II can be found in Kaddour and Hinton.12
Further publications are planned to compare the theoretical results with relevant experimental data for all the test cases.

def.p: stiffness component ij (ijkl) of the lamina
Young’s modulus of lamina for the i direction or for fiber or matrix
force component i(ij) per unit length acting on the laminate
volume fraction of fibers or matrix
strain component i(ij) of the lamina
strain component i(ij) of the laminate
stress component i(ij) of the lamina

Delta Kroniker (=1 for i = j and =0 for i ≠ j)

orthogonal to fiber direction of the lamina

sec.p: Failure criteria for brittle materials go back up to 1773, when the French scientist Coulomb, suggested that failure is due to internal friction which is dependent on the pressure. Recently, Rubin13 had developed failure criteria for minerals and sand where the strength is a function of the pressure. However, for ductile metals, which roughly obey Von Mises6 criterion, the shear strength is not a function of the hydrostatic pressure.

It is suggested here, that for materials with higher (in absolute values) uniaxial compressive strength than uniaxial tensile strength, the shear strength is a function of the isotropic stress σo (equation (2)). Because experimental data for this dependence is not available here, it is assumed that the function is bi-linear and is controlled by Fc and Ft, the uni-axial measured strengths that are available here. Since failure of homogenous materials does not occur due to hydrostatic pressure, it is estimated that Fco << Fc, which means that σo may be very high pressure. However, the effect on the shear strength is limited by the contraction of the material due to the pressure. Without experimental data we have to estimate this value. It is estimated here that the lower bound for the pressure influence on the shear strength is σo = 2/3 Fc (Note: σo = 1/3 Fc at uni-axial compressive failure).

Isotropic tension increase the distance between the molecules of the material without causing any shear stress. Failure mechanism is totally different than that of uniaxial tension. Therefore it is estimated that Fto = Ft/1.5 = 2/3 Ft (Note: σo = 1/3 Ft at uniaxial tensile failure). The calculations of equations (6) and (7) are demonstrated in Figure 13. Figure 13.
Dependence of the deviatory strength on the isotropic pressure.

The variations of moduli of a lamina with strain for the various unidirectional materials were expressed as functions derived from the provided data. The relevant expressions are shown below. It was assumed that outside the range of the provided data, the moduli remain unchanged. These are secant moduli.
